image_matrix.caption: My new little friend in Quito (1989).

Pichincha is an active volcano outside Quito, Ecuador. This Edward Whymper woodcut of 1892 shows three of Whymper's guides near the summit. Whymper was a famous naturalist, climber, and artist who climbed extensively in the Alps and the Andes. In 1880, he was the first climber to ascend a high altitude peak, in this case Chimborazo (20,400'). His signature appears in the lower left corner. See the delightful accounts of his climbs and travels in Travels Amongst the Great Andes of the Equator. R. Villarreal Collection.
Pichincha volcano summit (15,700', 4790 m).
This photo captures the 1999 eruption of Pichincha Volcano. I stood on the summit 12 years before this! Courtesy of Wikipedia.

El Cayambe (18,996', 5790 m) sits northeast of Quito. Its distinction is that the equator lies right on its southern slopes. We got this close to the peak before the guides determined that the entire lower portion of the Whymper route had been obliterated by avalanches. We pushed on to Cotopaxi.
Upon our departure from El Cayambe, I found another little friend, this one walking her dog.
Original 1892 Whymper woodcut of a puma approaching Whymper's tent on El Cayambe at 14,462' (4408 m). R. Villarreal Collection.
On the descent of El Cayambe, one of the pack animals slipped and fell over a precipice into the void below. Original 1892 Edward Whymper woodcut. R. Villarreal Collection.
Base Camp on Cotopaxi -- the Jose Rivas hut at 15,500' (4720 m).
Cotopaxi (19,347', 5897 m).
Another view of the Cotopaxi summit, this one higher on the route.
Whymper wood engraving dated 1892 of the Cotopaxi summit crater. R. Villarreal Collection.
On the return from the fog choked Cotopaxi summit, the mists lift to reveal the rich Ecuadorian countryside.
More stunning views from the flanks of Cotopaxi.
And more.
A section of the valley walls surrounding Banos, a small town near Tungurahua peak. It resembles Yosemite Valley, with numerous waterfalls that cascade into the valley below.
On the way from Banos to the Tungurahua staging area to rent our pack animals.
Pack horse for lugging our gear to a refugio on the slopes of Tungurahua volcano (16,475', 5022 m); next day it was too windy to climb.
The Tungurahua hut at 13,000' (4000 m). The wind was blasting the next morning so viciously that we cancelled an attempt on the summit.
This same Tungurahua erupting in April, 2011; the beautiful town of Banos is off to the left.
Another picture of the eruption.
We're on the way to the Carrel hut on Chimborazo (in the distance). Photo taken from Guarandas.

1899 original halftone print of Chimborazo by The Werner Company. This image is from Guarandas, very near the spot where I took the picture in the previous image. In both, the Whymper route to the summit is out of sight, over the ridge on the left skyline. R. Villarreal Collection.
This wood-engraving hunting scene most likely was carried out in the area of the previous picture of Chimborazo, near Guarandas. It's another Whymper work dated 1885. R. Villarreal Collection.
The Louis Carrel hut on Chimborazo, at 15,912' (4850 m). Carrel was one of Whymper's climbing guides in Ecuador.
A look down to the Carrel hut on the way up to the Base Camp location of the Whymper hut.
The Whymper hut at 16,404' (5000 m). Courtesy Summit Post.

A view of Chimborazo from the Whymper hut. The route follows the ridge to the right. Once above the rock and ice outcropping in the center of the picture, the route traverses to the left skyline and follows the glacier to the summit.
On the top; I'm on the left with our Ecuadorian guide.
Original 1892 Edward Whymper woodcut as he and his guides try to erect their tent low on the slopes of Chimborazo. R. Villarreal Collection.
Another Whymper engraving showing climbers, at 17,450' (5319 m), above the site of today's Whymper hut as they work their way across the ridge outside camp. R. Villarreal Collection.
Whymper's engraving of the scene higher on the route, at 18,500' (5640 m). R. Villarreal Collection.
Whymper engraving of the route as they close on the summit. R. Villarreal Collection.

Louis Carrel contracted frostbite on the climb. A litter was rigged up and he was carried to the nearby town of Ambato for medical treatment Another 1892 woodcut by Edward Whymper. R. Villarreal Collection.
La Paz, with Illimani in the distance (1991).
1931 original photogravure by Atlantis-Verlag of La Paz, with Illimani in the distance. R. Villarreal Collection.
Our llama arrieros load the animals for the hike into Condoriri and Pequeno Alpamayo.
On the way to Alpamayo.
Pequeno Alpamayo (17,558', 5352 m).
A view to the west.
We inch our way up.
On the top.
On the top with a rope mate.
Cerro Huayna Potosi (19,968', 6086 m).
One rope team nears the summit, out of sight to the right.
We approach a small village on the way to Base Camp. Illimani in distance (21,122', 6438 m).
Above the little village.
Another view.
We near Base Camp.
On the summit.
Our descent down the mountain.

The Tiwanaku (or Tiahuanaco) complex, looking north. Tiahuanaco is a Pre-Colombian archaeological site in western Bolivia. It was the capital of an empire that extended into present-day Peru and Chile, flourishing from AD 300 to AD 1000. The temple complex of Kalasasaya is in the center of the scene. The following pictures show much of the present-day site.
Staircase and entrance door of the Kalasasaya Temple.
Interior walls of the Semi-subterranean Temple with the \"embedded heads\" on its walls.
Another view of the Semi-subterranean Temple courtyard.
The Ponce monolith in the Kalasasaya complex.
The Gateway of the Sun. It stands 10 feet high and 13 feet wide.

Original 1888 wood engraving of Aconcagua, artist unknown. The view is east. Aconcagua was first climbed in 1897 over the western walls by Matthias Zurbriggen, a member of the expedition led by E. A. Fitzgerald. Publisher: Harper & Brothers. R. Villarreal Collection.
An original 1913 half-tone print of Aconcagua. The view is east. Creator: G.P. Putnam's and Sons. R. Villarreal Collection.
At the trailhead of the Rio de las Vacas for the first day of the hike towards the peak.
We cross the de las Vacas later the first day.
A stretch of the de las Vacas on our way to Camp II at Casa de la Piedra.
Our Camp at Casa de la Piedra. The first view of Aconcagua is from this point.
A climber checks out the stone \"house.\" Courtesy of mza com ar.
In the afternoon of the second day, we reach Casa de Piedra for our second camp; Aconcagua is in the distance. The view is west.
Hiking up the Relinchos Valley to Base Camp; Aconcagua on the left, Ameghino on the right.
More of the Relinchos Valley.
The Relinchos stream.
Somewhere in the Relinchos Valley.
Rest stop on the stream.
Approaching Base Camp.
Our Base Camp at 13,000' (4000 m).
An arriero at Base Camp.
Our pack animals.
Above nieves penitentes on the way to Camp I.
A look down the Relinchos River Valley from just below Camp I.
Camp I.
The hike to Camp II at the foot of the Polish Glacier.
Progress towards Camp II.
Getting close.
Camp II - taking a break.
More of Camp II.
The view of Mercedario in the east.
Another vista from Camp II.
And another.
Looking up the impressive Polish Glacier; our route is in the ice and snow to the left.
We left Camp II at 1 AM; here we are at the top of the Glacier looking down its expanse.

We leave our rest stop at the top of the Glacier and strike out for the summit; I'm the one behind the climber immediately in picture. Behind stretches the Relinchos Valley all the way to Casa de Piedra on the de las Vacas. This is one of the most highly sought-after photos of the route pioneered by the Poles in 1934 along their route up the eastern slopes of the great peak. R. Villarreal Collection.
Making steady progress.
One of the team has an upset stomach.
We keep moving higher.
The view to the southwest.

As we approach the summit, a look back down the ridge of our ascent. The rock pinnacles seen in A.26 are just to the left and below the end of the ice ridge. Farther to the left, the Relinchos Valley is in the near distance, with the de las Vacas river in the far distance.
A rest stop near the summit.

We're there! I'm on the left.
22,834' (6960 m)
Team photo on the summit.
We descend by way of the Canaleta on the western slopes. A thousand feet lower we traverse around the northern slopes to the eastern side for the return back to Base.
To prevent my frostbitten toes from becoming wet, my friends carry me across the Rio de las Vacas.
Group shot back at Puente del Inca. Though my right toes and fingers were frostbitten, the climb was worth it.
Cerro Mercedario (22,047', 6720 m), looking east, from high on Aconcagua.

name: Chapter 1 | Nevado Ojos del Salado, Chile: Ghosts of the Conquistadors

image_matrix.caption: General Orientation map showing peaks chronicled in Clawing for the Stars: A Solo Climber in the Highest Andes.
This map shows many of the peaks and other places of interest mentioned in the chapters. Ojos del Salado is south of the Great Plateau on the border with Argentina.
Giancarlo at the rear of his truck with James on the roof.
The scene from the Pass, with Laguna Santa Rosa below and Tres Cruces in the distance.
The Santa Rosa Refugio with Giancarlo's Land Cruiser alongside.
Giancarlo on the way into the old Carabinero Station, which has been relocated to the shores of Laguna Verde since this photo was taken in 1992.
Our Base Camp at 14,800' (4510 m); in the distance, El Muerto (21,286', 6488 m) is on the left and Ojos on the right.
A storm buries Ojos. R. Villarreal Collection.

image_matrix.caption: Early morning scene with the moon still visible.
On the road to the Atacama Refugio.
Refugio Atacama (16,730', 5100 m). Although it looks quite spartan, it's actually quite comfortable.
A stream fed by snowfields higher on the mountain flows by Atacama.
The road leading to Refugio Tejos (18,860', 5750 m). It's hard to believe a road exists this high.
Another shot of the road.
On the way to the Tejos Refugio with the Atacama far below. A road this high is unheard of! R. Villarreal Collection.
image_matrix.label: A2

image_matrix.caption: The Refugio is right behind me. The imposing northern face of Ojos del Salado (22,609', 6891 m).
Another view from Tejos.
Another view. The sphinx-like paw of the First Step is partially in view. One may discern the other four steps above proceeding towards the summit. I placed my camp above Tejos on the First Step.
My First Step camp.
Another shot; El Muerto in the distance.
View of El Muerto from the Third Step.
Looking back down the Steps.
Another view: the First Step quite a ways down.

On top of the Fifth Step looking over at El Muerto (21,247', 6476 m). El Fraile (19,614', 5978 m) is in the mid-distance with Incahuasi (21,651', 6599 m) farther on. Summit is behind me and a little higher.

View from the summit looking south/southwest. In the near distance on the right is Cazadero (aka Walter Penck). At 21,838' (6656 m) it is the ninth highest peak. Farther on to the left is the darkened mass of Nacimiento (21,126', 6439 m). In the far distance is Pissis (22,287', 6793 m), the third highest peak.
From the summit: Tres Cruces rises in the west, with Central on the left and Sur on the right.
James signs the summit register. This wasn't exactly his best side!
Looking into the mouth of the summit crater.
Self photo after James leaves.
We descend by way of the massive north face; the Tejos refugio is barely visible far below.
A magnificent sunset from our Base Camp.
We depart the Ojos region on the return to Copiapo. Barrancas Blancas on the right, Ojos del Salado in the center, and El Muerto to the left. R. Villarreal Collection.

name: Chapter 2 | Monte Pissis, Argentina: High Winds from Tartarus

March 1994: My first visit to Pissis (Chap. 2). We spend the first night here, the Refugio at Laguna Negro Francisco.
A bofedal near Refugio Negro Francisco.
Giancarlo's friends plot out how to get to the peak.
Looking north from Laguna Negro Francisco to Cerro Copiapo as a storm moves in from the west (from the left in the photo).
The pyramid marking Valle Ancho Pass.
Somewhere on the way. Giancarlo on right.
My Base Camp at 15,900' (4850 m). This is high for Base. It snowed the morning after Giancarlo and his friends left.
This is the view north. What if it snows near to my pick up day?
Self photo in nieves penitentes field on the way to Camp I.
Another penitentes field.
Camp I at 17,600' (5360 m).
More penitentes on way to Camp II.
Camp II at 17,900' (5460 m). In the east is Pissis; the broad ice field prevents access.
Another view of the western walls of Pissis.
Bonete Chico (22,169', 6757 m) is in the distance.
Another view of the scene; the subsidiary peak on the right is where I placed Camp.
Another view.
More of the ice field.

On top of the subsidiary peak, a look down on the ice field and a look over at Pissis.
And more.
The western walls once more.
Alpenglow brightens the western walls of Pissis. Taken from atop the subsidiary summit.

After Giancarlo and his friends picked me up on the western side, they took me around to the eastern side. This is the site of my Base Camp, at 16,000' (4900 m). The normal route on Pissis follows the left side of the glacier.
More of the eastern side.
My Base Camp on the eastern slopes.
Looking north on pick-up morning. There's no snow out there!

name: Chapter 3 | Llullaillaco, Chile: A Case of Mistaken Identity

image_matrix.caption: This is the map we used to find our way to Llullaillaco.
Maria Ester and Giancarlo in sunnier times.
Giancarlo and I plan at the La Casona bar.
On the way to Llullaillaco for my first visit - November, 1994. Pan-American highway gas station 100 miles south of Antofagasta. I hope we have enough spare tires!
Llullaillaco is in the distance. Because of the landmine threat, we dare not leave the road.
A beautiful mountain.
Laguna Aguas Calientes. The abandoned borax mine is just visible on the left shoreline.
Giancarlo checks one of the rooms.
Veils of steam on Lastarria to the south.

The author has examined this photogravure closely and is convinced that it is the abandoned mine on the shores of Laguna Aguas Calientes that Giancarlo, Patricio, and he stayed at their first nights out to Llullaillaco. The Laguna is to the right. The mine buildings are somewhat indistinct. Still, their outlines suggest it is the Calientes mine. The overwhelming proof is that the peak to the right is surely Lastarria in its appearance and the mountain on the left is assuredly Llullaillaco. 1916 Original Photogravure of a Chilean Desert Borax Field. Publisher: The Mentor. R. Villarreal Collection.
Alpenglow on my \"Flaming Mountain.\"
Base Camp. Baby Blue is on the left. A tarp covers my gear, food, and water.
The lava flow, as I approach Camp I.
Looking back down the way from Camp.
Camp I.
Looking up the route to Camp II, somewhere up there.
Inside Blue.
My shadow on an ice bank.
Camp II.
Camp III on the fringe of the ice plateau. The peak I thought the principal summit is behind me.

The peak I thought the main one.
On the top, with Argentina stretching out before me.
The true summit.
More Argentina.
As I gaze upon it, I wonder what went wrong.

name: Chapter 4 | Closing the Circle on Llullaillaco, Chile

image_matrix.caption: Patricio catches some winks at the mine.
Flamingoes on Laguna Aguas Calientes. The borax mine is in the distance.
Patricio casts a long shadow.
Sunset, with Lastarria to the south.

Next morning, Pat has left for the long ride back to Copiapo.
Another golden moment on this peak.
Base Camp at 14,600' (4450 m).
So far, it's nice and pleasant on this trip.

Camp I, or Camp \"Apricot\". Were there other climbers on the mountain?
I've been at this spot before. The lava flow in the distance.
My Camp II.
At the ice plateau's edge. Within minutes of taking this picture, I began to feel a \"presence\" nearby.
My Camp III site, looking up the ravine.

My Camp III. The top of Blue is just visible. The \"presence\" remained on the plateau and did not follow me here. Next morning, summit day, the high winds were such that I had to abandon my summit attempt.
Preparing for summit day.

name: Chapter 5 | Nevado Tres Cruces, Chile: The Cracking of the Will

My first close look at Tres Cruces. Central is on the left and Sur on the right.

Back at Base. A golden alpenglow on Sur.

name: Chapter 7 | Monte Pissis, Argentina: The Hand of God

image_matrix.caption: Giancarlo's cross on Laguna Negro Francisco where his body was found.
At La Casona, waiting for Patricio. Of course, I had no idea what was about to take place on Pissis. Maria Ester is behind the camera.

A small stream from an ojo immediately below Ancho Pass.

My Base Camp, at 15,500' (4720 m), on the northern slopes. The main summit is the one on the right. My route will proceed through the gully below the summit to a Camp I. Higher, I will traverse to the right, or west, to reach a Camp II.
Base Camp looking northeast.
Another ojo! This one is next to Base.
A rest stop on the way to Camp I.

Inside Blue at II.

Camp III at 20,200' (6160 m). I'm looking up the gully that will take me higher. There is a steep dropoff right behind me.
Camp III. This is the site of the infamous stove \"incident.\"
On the way to the subsidiary summit. Early in the morning, the top of the main summit was cloaked in clouds, making it too risky to attempt.
Scenery along the way.
Still climbing towards the subsidiary summit, as I look over at the main summit. The clouds have now lifted.
Still going.
The view of the main summit as I approach the top of my peak.
I'm finally on the top of Pissis West I, at 22,135' (6747 m) (this peak was named several years after this climb). I'm positive this is a first solo ascent.
West II , at 22,074' (6720 m), from West I. The view is south.
More of West II.
More views from the top of the sub summit.
The \"Crater\" summit in the distance, looking south.
Stunning views.
More subsidiary summits to the east.
It has been a satisfying climb.
The southwestern shores of Laguna Negro Francisco. The Refugio is right behind me.
The look north at Cerro Copiapo (19,836', 6046 m) from the shores of Laguna Negro Francisco.
Another look north to Cerro Copiapo.
The look north to Cerro Copiapo with the cross in the upper foreground that marked where Giancarlo passed away in the water and sand.

name: Chapter 8 | Llullaillaco, Chile: How Did Those Guys Do It, Anyway?

name: Chapter 10 | Tres Cruces, Chile: The Last Climb

image_matrix.caption: One of several oases on the Mina Marte road leading to the pass overlooking Laguna Santa Rosa.
November, 2009. At the pass, looking across to Tres Cruces.
Looking down upon Laguna Santa Rosa.
Another view.
And another.
The author on the shores of the Laguna.
On Chile Highway 31, with Tres Cruces in the distance.
My Base Camp, with the winds howling.
A night at Advanced Base Camp.	The winds have yet to lessen in force.	I slept inside the truck since it was impossible to set Blue up.

image_matrix.label: A1

image_matrix.caption: A last look back at Tres Cruces.
After retreating from the mountain, I stop to visit the Carabinero Station at Laguna Verde. The wind was so strong it almost tore the door from my hands.
I returned to Santa Rosa to spend the night at the Refugio.
This and the following pictures are views of the Laguna's shores as I traveled north almost twelve miles.
Santa Rosa.
An hour after this photo of Tres Cruces, it was enveloped once more in clouds.
Santa Rosa.
Santa Rosa.
Santa Rosa.
The sun sets and ends another Andean day. It also heralds the close of my wonderful Andean climbing career.
Next day, a last goodbye before returning to Copiapo.
A last goodbye from the pass. R. Villarreal Collection.

De Mérida and Ancohualla met Apani in Atacama (today's San Pedro de Atacama) and heard his story of how the Indians built the huts on the summit of Llullaillaco. A modern-day street scene in this charming town. Courtesy of visitchile.com.

Angastu (Antofagasta) was the jump-off point for Llullaillaco. We can only infer from the information presented in the recording of the conversation with Apani that the effort to place huts on the summit of the peak began in late August 1494.
Today's Antofagasta is a bustling port city of 345,000 people. Courtesy of misionlatinoamericana.
It really does snow in the Atacama Desert! Courtesy aljazeera.com. Also, see Chapter 6, Clawing for the Stars, for the author's experiences with Atacama snow storms.
A source of water on the way to Monturaqui.
And another.
This was the supply location for men, goods, and equipment on their way to Llullaillaco. The summit of the peak is just in view to the south.
This is one of several building ruins next to Monturaqui. These no doubt go back to the time of Apani.
A water source on the way from Monturaqui to the western side of the mountain.

The northern end of Laguna Aguas Calientes, which sits below the western side of the peak. Vitahuati and his men had first planned to climb to the summit by way of the western walls. R. Villarreal Collection.
This area would have served well as a Base Camp on the western side for Vita and his men. R. Villarreal Collection.
This area would have made a good first camp site, at 16,500', for the cunturs as they labored up the western slopes. R. Villarreal Collection.
This spot, at 18,300', might have served the cunturs well as the next higher camp on the western side. R. Villarreal Collection.
This is the plateau, at 19,300', where Apani said the cunturs realized the western side was too steep from here to the summit and chose to turn around and descend. R. Villarreal Collection.

Vitahuati and his men decided to search for a suitable route to the summit somewhere else on the peak. No doubt they had a similar view of the northern slopes on their way around the mountain, as pictured here. R. Villarreal Collection.
Vitahuati and the cunturs led the traverse past these northwest walls in search of a route to the top. R. Villarreal Collection.
